text: The great thing about betting pre-market is that you can use the BSP (final price) to calculate the probabilities of the outcomes. If your matched prices are better than those then you are +EV (this is how I am betting)

elements.text: The great thing about betting pre-market is that you can use the BSP (final price) to calculate the probabilities of the outcomes. If your matched prices are better than those then you are +EV (this is how I am betting)

text:
Always remember that the market efficiency increases as more money is traded (aka "wisdom of the crowd"), so in _theory,_ a £500K market will be more efficient than a £100K market. The probabilities for each runner will conclude at either 100% (winner) or 0% (loser). From market opening to market closure, the prices are constantly moving, which by it's very nature indicates that there is uncertainty and inefficiency in the market and _that_ is what you need to exploit. Breaking it down into micro markets triggered by price moves, money flow, etc helps. Think about _why_ the price moved and _how_ the market reports it. You don't have to know that the horse was playing up or the trainer made some comment on TV, all you need to know is if it has a positive or negative effect on the prices and volumes.

You _can_ try to predict the winners or losers using fundamental or statistical analysis but it's a highly competitive approach and would likely require some extremely complicated modelling to beat the market makers.

Simple (and obvious) mathematical approaches DO make a profit but can be difficult to execute optimally, e.g. lay the field at > 100% book, lay 4 runners at < 4.0, back the drifters, lay the steamers, etc. Don't be afraid to oppose what everyone else seems to doing. The horses don't know how much money is being traded and I can tell you with 100% certainty that "insider" knowledge doesn't make a horse win. I live in an agricultural area and know a handful of people that work in the racing industry. If I had £1 for every time I've been told "our horse will win today" (and it didn't), I'd be a lot richer than if I was backing them. Hell, I regularly see these horses get backed from 14/1 into 5/1 and they still don't win, so even the "insiders" get it wrong more often than they get it right.

text: What are people's thoughts on trying to piggy-back on the smart money, i.e. looking for big price movements caused by syndicates close to the off and then betting accordingly?

elements.text: What are people's thoughts on trying to piggy-back on the smart money, i.e. looking for big price movements caused by syndicates close to the off and then betting accordingly?

text: You'd have to ask yourself whether it's a good idea to go over what they think is an appropriate stake

elements.text: You'd have to ask yourself whether it's a good idea to go over what they think is an appropriate stake

text: Yes that's the issue I would see with it, whether whatevers left to bet on is still value.  I've back tested on 5 years worth of horse racing data and it _seems_ like it could work (in certain markets), but the proof would be in live testing obviously.

elements.text: Yes that's the issue I would see with it, whether whatevers left to bet on is still value.  I've back tested on 5 years worth of horse racing data and it
seems
like it could work (in certain markets), but the proof would be in live testing obviously.

text: It's possible, but how do you know what movements are caused by the big syndicates? You have to pick up the movements early and bet as soon as you see them

elements.text: It's possible, but how do you know what movements are caused by the big syndicates? You have to pick up the movements early and bet as soon as you see them

text: True, I guess you don't need to know if it's a big syndicate or not, it could just be looking at big price movements, whether that's caused by syndicates or not.  It might of course be caused by a mug punter chasing a loss, but on average you'd think that those sorts of bets would be drowned out by smarter money.

text: It might be possible, if you have enough background knowledge and skill, to identify movements generated by the largest and best of the syndicates. Their POT% is high, their turnover is huge, and I know that getting a fraction of that POT% and turnover would easily beat a full-time wage. I had thought about it in the past, but decided that it's a pretty risky strategy totally reliant on someone else

text: If a price has moved then it's probably moved towards 0EV, so you'd have to consider whether whatever value was there before is now reduced or  perhaps eliminated. That doesn't mean you can't make this idea work though - it's worth researching any idea you might have because with sufficient effort there's a good chance that you'll either make it work or (more likely in this case) learn from the process and move towards something that does work.

text: If you analyse prices that have just moved (the movement is in the past) then you will find that the pre-movement price will show value - that's why it moved. That's no use to you though because that price is gone, you need to find a price that's value now - and therefore about to move.

elements.text: If you analyse prices that have just moved (the movement is in the past) then you will find that the pre-movement price will show value - that's why it moved. That's no use to you though because that price is gone, you need to find a price that's value now - and therefore about to move.

text: Last point - if a single player pushes a price towards their model price, that doesn't mean it is pushed towards 0EV. That assumes their model is correct, which we know cannot possibly be so all the time

elements.text: Last point - if a single player pushes a price towards their model price, that doesn't mean it is pushed towards 0EV. That assumes their model is correct, which we know cannot possibly be so all the time

elements.text: On aggregate prices move towards 0EV.

text: It's why two different models betting on the same races can both be very profitable. You only have to be right more often than not

text: At any given time there is a 0EV price. There must be or there couldn't be a +EV or -EV price. Any given model may or may not get it right but it still exists. Two models may produce different prices for a particular instant for a particular bet and both models may be profitable overall but that doesn't mean that they both priced that bet correctly.

elements.text: At any given time there is a 0EV price. There must be or there couldn't be a +EV or -EV price. Any given model may or may not get it right but it still exists. Two models may produce different prices for a particular instant for a particular bet and both models may be profitable overall but that doesn't mean that they both priced that bet correctly.
